ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Take it. If you've taken GR before, take this again -- there will certainly be important things that you've missed. If you've never taken it before, you're in for a treat. The reason is that he is very good at explaining abstract things in terms that students can understand. For example, talking about atlases/maps at the beginning helped make things very concrete.

Definitely recommend! Really cool material, including gravitational waves to black holes. Prof. Moncrief was a great instructor in this class -- I think he's underrated as a professor. He has a knack for explaining really complicated stuff in a waythat helps you gain intuition without obscuring the technical details. He was always available outside of class and was super helpful if you came to him with questions. I found the textbook (Wald) to be pretty dense, so I spent some time with Sean Carroll's GR lecture notes on arXiv. The exams were tricky, but they were take-home, and so that gives you a chance to really bang your head against them. Which means you end up learning things. One feature of the class this semester was that there were a lot more undergrads than grads, but I'm not sure if that affected the pace of the class compared to a more grad-heavy class.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I'd be lost in my current research project if it weren't for this course.
